key_title: Key to the species of Geranium

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Geraniaceae

source.author: Smith, L.P.
source.title: Geranium
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Smith, L.P. (1999). Geranium. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves palmatisect or almost ternate with 3–5 primary lobes; primary lobes (particularly centre lobe) pinnatisect to c. bipinnatisect (usually 2 or more pairs of secondary lobes); garden-escapes
Leaves palmatifid to palmatisect with 3–9 primary lobes; primary lobes bifid, trifid or variously lobed but never truly pinnatisect (or never more than 2 pairs of c. opposite secondary lobes)
Petals 18–22 mm long; mericarps without long hair-like fibres
Petals to 15 mm long; tufts of long hair-like fibres attached at top of mericarp either side of dorsal suture near awn attachment
Flowers small, petals 5–9 mm long; foliage not malodorous; anthers yellow; mericarps with dense wrinkle-like ridges (see note after genus description)
Flowers large, petals 8–14 mm long; foliage malodorous; anthers orange to purple; mericarps with sparse, (usually) fine ridges
Plants glabrous to glabrescent (sometimes with isolated hairs or with inconspicuous indumentum of tiny appressed hairs)
Plants (particularly peduncles, pedicels and leaf surfaces) with a conspicuous (sparse to dense) indumentum
Plants glabrous or with minute retrorse and strongly-appressed hairs on stems and petioles; leaf surfaces usually with tiny appressed or curved hairs
Petioles and stems with very few scattered, retrorse or recurved to subappressed hairs, stems often glabrescent with age; leaf surfaces with isolated to scattered hairs

Basal leaves persisting throughout year; plants freely rooting from nodes along elongate flowering stem, or plant rosetted, without elongate flowering stems (or with very short stems never exceeding basal leaves); roots thickened and fibrous, often matted, sometimes with woody taproot; swamps and poorly-drained sites, often alpine or subalpine

Basal leaves usually senescing before or during stem elongation; plants not (or rarely) rooting from nodes; taproot napiform or thickened and tapering, sometimes with lateral branching but never fibrous and matted; habitat various but not swamp-inhabiting

Plants green to dark green; senescent leaves bright red to orange; flowers large (to 3 cm diam.), pink with darker veins and usually with long pedicel/peduncle (to 25 cm); sepals pubescent; flowering stems lax, with internodes often exceeding 20 cm long, extensively rooting from nodes; seeds with very small yet distinct isodiametric alveolae; East Gippsland, not alpine or subalpine

Plants usually greyish; senescent leaves never bright red to orange; flowers small (to 9 mm diam.), pale pink, usually sessile; sepals pilose; flowering stems (if present) never exceeding basal leaves; seeds smooth, with very shallow indistinct alveolae; alps and subalps

Pedicels/peduncles never with long glandular hairs; sepals often vertically infolded or concave in fruit; seeds slightly rugose with small, shallow, c. isodiametric alveolae; usually robust, much-branched plants of damp, weedy sites

Pedicels/peduncles with occasional long, patent glandular hairs (sometimes deciduous with age); sepals never folded deeply inwards in fruit; seeds smooth with very shallow c. oblong alveolae; fine, trailing to scrambling plant of damp, sheltered areas of north-east
At least inner sepals with broad hyaline margins; sepals usually reflexed in spent fruits; mericarps sparsely hairy, without distinctly ciliate suture margins; seeds with small, elongate alveolae
Sepals without obvious hyaline margins; sepals rarely reflexed in spent fruit; mericarps pubescent with distinctly ciliate suture margins; seeds with large, isodia- metric alveolae

Plants rosetted, if flowering stem ever developed, then never exceeding basal leaves; sepals hirsute to villous with long whitish hairs and apical mucro 1.3–2 mm long; higher-montane forests, subalpine and alpine grasslands and herbfields

Plants forming elongate flowering stems far exceeding basal leaves (rosetted only during overwintering stage); sepals variously hairy, not densely hirsute or villous, mucro rarely exceeding 1 mm long; habitats various, never truly alpine
Pedicel/peduncle to c. 8 cm long at anthesis (rarely subsessile); pedicel/ peduncle indumentum antrorse to c. patent; petals bright pink, exceeding sepals
Flowers usually sessile at anthesis (pedicels elongating in fruit); pedicel/peduncle indumentum usually dense, retrorse; petals narrow, red-purple, not exceeding sepals
Indumentum of stems strongly retrorse-appressed
Indumentum of stems variously spreading to somewhat retrorse (but not strongly appressed)

Leaves shallowly or deeply incised, lobes not narrow-linear, never appearing 'tangled'; sepal mucro very short (under 0.5 mm) or absent; at least pedicel and peduncle with occasional long patent glandular hairs; apparently confined to moist sheltered sites

Leaves deeply dissected, lobes narrow-linear, usually appearing 'tangled'; sepal mucro distinct (usually 0.5–1 mm long); indumentum not including long glandular hairs; usually dry sites in grasslands and grassy woodlands
Flowers bright pink to magenta (sometimes fading to pink); anthers without blue dehiscence lines; indumentum always retrorse and strongly appressed on petioles, stems and (usually) pedicel/peduncle

Flowers pale pink; anthers with faint blue dehiscence lines; indumentum sometimes retrorse-appressed on late-season growth but lower stems, basal petioles and pedicel/peduncle pubescent with very short recurved to long, patent hairs
Indumentum, particularly on pedicel and peduncle, tomentose, puberulous or pubescent, sometimes greyish, with dense, very short, soft, often recurved hairs
Indumentum, particularly on pedicel and peduncle, conspicuously spreading, recurved or retrorse, not consistently very short and dense

Flowers never more than 18 mm diam.; inflorescence always 1-flowered (rarely 2- or 3-flowered through monochasial growth); inner sepals sometimes with narrow-translucent margins but never with retuse apices; mericarp without ciliate suture margins

Flowers large (18–25 mm diam.), mostly twinned, but often single and twinned on same plant; at least inner sepals with broad-translucent margins and more or less retuse apices; mericarp with shortly ciliate suture margins
Stems (or at least petioles) pilose to villous, including at least some long patent hairs
Stems with short to long, retrorse to recurved (but not patent) hairs
Leaf-lobes usually narrow to narrow-linear; anther dehiscence lines pale to dark blue-purple
Leaf-lobes broad, never narrow-linear; anther dehiscence lines obscure, not coloured

Petals bright pink to magenta (sometimes fading to pink but never pale pink or white), discolorous, veins rather obscure; sepal mucro usually longer than 0.5 mm; stems with hairs predominantly spreading at right angles
Petals pale pink to white, concolorous, with 3–5 translucent veins; sepal mucro usually shorter than 0.5 mm; older stems with retrorse to appressed indumentum

Mericarps glabrous and strongly wrinkled; seed retained within mericarp on ripening; petals dark pink-magenta, incised or bilobed; indumentum villous with shining hairs; annual or biennial with short, narrow taproot

Mericarps puberulous to pubescent, rarely with longer hairs toward awn, smooth; seed released from mericarp on ripening; petals white to pale pink, c. obtuse, never incised or bilobed; hairs not shining; perennial with napiform to ellipsoid taproot

Plants annual or biennial with narrow taproot and/or fibrous roots; petals magenta, deeply incised or bilobed; stipules usually reddish; at least upper stems covered in long glandular and eglandular hairs; fruit rostrum with long glandular hairs; garden-escape, often growing on wasteland

Plants perennial with swollen napiform to ellipsoid taproot; petals mid-pink to whitish, never deeply incised or bilobed; stipules never reddish; stems and inflo- rescences without long glandular hairs; fruit rostrum eglandular

Sepal mucro less than 0.5 mm long; roots napiform to ellipsoid, not branched (rarely forked); mericarps with long-ciliate suture margins; anther dehiscence lines obscure; upper surfaces of leaves (and stems) not tuberculate

Sepal mucro at least 0.5 mm long; roots thickened, branched or tapering below but not napiform; mericarps without ciliate suture margins; anther dehiscence lines fine, purplish or bluish; upper surfaces of leaves (and stems) often tuberculate

Sepals elliptic and/or obovate, at least the two inner ones obovate with broad hyaline margins, mucro usually 1–1.5 mm long; seed reddish-brown with small, shallow, elongate alveolae; stems usually glabrescent or glabrous; upper surfaces of leaves glabrescent to sparsely hispid

Sepals ovate to lanceolate, margins narrow, white to translucent (never broad and hyaline), mucro usually less than 1 mm long; seed dark brown with large, deep, isodiametric alveolae; stems densely hispid or sometimes glabrescent; upper surfaces of leaves hispid
